Not unfamiliar to mine ear,</br>Blasts of the night!  ye howl as now</br>My shudd'ring casement loud</br>With fitful voice ye beat.
Mine ear has dwelt in silent awe,</br>The howling sweep, the sudden rush;</br>And when the pausing gale</br>Pour'd deep the hollow dirge.
Once more I listen; — sadly communing</br>Within me — once more mark, storm-cloth'd,</br>The moon, as the dark cloud</br>Glides rapidly away.
I, deeming that the voice of spirits dwells</br>In these mysterious moans, in solemn thought,</br>Muse on the choral dance</br>The dead-man's jubilee.
Hark, how the spirit knocks, how loud</br>Ev'n at my window knocks — again—</br>I cannot, dare not sleep—</br>It is a boist'rous night.
I would not, at this moment, be</br>In the drear forest-groves, to hear</br>This uproar and rude song</br>Ring o'er the arched aisles.
The ear doth shudder at such sounds</br>As the unbodied winds, in their disport,</br>Make in the hollow woods</br>When man is gone to sleep.
There have been heard, unchristian shrieks</br>And rude distemper'd merriment,</br>As tho' the autumnal bands</br>Were all in morrice dance.
There's mystery in these sounds:  and I</br>Love not to have the grave disturb'd,</br>And dismal trains arise</br>From the unpeopled tombs.
Spirits, I pray ye, let them sleep</br>Peaceful in their cold graves, nor waft</br>The sear and whisp'ring leaf</br>From the inhumed breast.</br>
